articles.headline: In a Crackdown, Zimbabwe Curbs Aid Groups
articles.snippet: The government has clamped down on aid groups it claims are backing the opposition, relief agencies say.
articles.abstract: The government has clamped down on aid groups it claims are backing the opposition, relief agencies say.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  Hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of Zimbabweans  orphans and old people, the sick and the down and out  have lost access to food and other basic humanitarian assistance as their government has clamped down on international aid groups it says are backing the political opposition, relief agencies say.

articles.headline: Next on Agenda Is Clinton’s Role
articles.snippet: Barack Obama now faces the task of repairing relations with Hillary Rodham Clinton and deciding whether to offer her a spot on his ticket.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama now faces the task of repairing relations with Hillary Rodham Clinton and deciding whether to offer her a spot on his ticket.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama heads into the general election with obvious advantages: He is a Democratic candidate running in a sour atmosphere for Republicans, in a contest where voters are hungry for change and coming out of a campaign in which he filled arena after arena with supporters.

articles.headline: G.M. Shifts Focus to Small Cars in Sign of Sport Utility Demise
articles.snippet: With no end in sight for elevated gas prices, G.M. announced drastic cuts in production of sport utility vehicles and pickups and stepped up plans for smaller cars.
articles.abstract: With no end in sight for elevated gas prices, G.M. announced drastic cuts in production of sport utility vehicles and pickups and stepped up plans for smaller cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Even General Motors, the steadfast champion of big sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, is thinking small now.

articles.headline: Big Vehicles Stagger Under the Weight of $4 Gas
articles.snippet: The growing costs of auto ownership are leading Americans to change their driving habits quickly.
articles.abstract: The growing costs of auto ownership are leading Americans to change their driving habits quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: A fully loaded Ford F-250 pickup truck is a whole lot of vehicle. It can tow a horse trailer with multiple horses. It comes with a DVD-based navigation system for the driver as well as a DVD player for passengers who are sitting in the extended cab.

articles.headline: Rating Firms Seem Near Legal Deal on Reforms
articles.snippet: Under fire for the high ratings they awarded to subprime mortgage securities, three large credit rating firms are close to announcing a broad deal with the New York attorney general.
articles.abstract: Under fire for the high ratings they awarded to subprime mortgage securities, three large credit rating firms are close to announcing a broad deal with the New York attorney general.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under fire for the high ratings they awarded to subprime mortgage securities, three large credit rating firms are close to announcing a broad deal with the New York attorney general to reform some of their core business practices, according to people briefed on the investigation.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Barack Obama: Calm in the Swirl of History
articles.snippet: Mr. Obama is a protean figure who inspires devotion in his supporters but remains inscrutable to critics.
articles.abstract: Mr. Obama is a protean figure who inspires devotion in his supporters but remains inscrutable to critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: He gives the appearance of a strikingly laid-back victor, this presumptive Democratic presidential nominee.

articles.headline: Icahn Wants New Chief for Yahoo
articles.snippet: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn vowed to remove Jerry Yang, Yahoo’s chief executive, if he succeeds in replacing the company’s board with his own slate of directors.
articles.abstract: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn vowed to remove Jerry Yang, Yahoo’s chief executive, if he succeeds in replacing the company’s board with his own slate of directors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The investor Carl C. Icahn stepped up the pressure on Yahoo on Tuesday, vowing to remove Jerry Yang, its chief executive, if he succeeds in replacing the company’s board with his own slate of directors.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Obama Clinches Nomination; First Black Candidate to Lead a Major Party Ticket
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama secured the Democratic presidential nomination on Tuesday evening after a primary campaign that inspired millions of voters.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama secured the Democratic presidential nomination on Tuesday evening after a primary campaign that inspired millions of voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama claimed the Democratic presidential nomination on Tuesday evening, prevailing through an epic battle with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in a primary campaign that inspired millions of voters from every corner of America to demand change in Washington.

articles.headline: In Hiring, Europeans Go Global
articles.snippet: As pressure grows on European businesses to go global, European companies are breaking down the glass ceiling that has long reserved their top spots for a local.
articles.abstract: As pressure grows on European businesses to go global, European companies are breaking down the glass ceiling that has long reserved their top spots for a local.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  When José Luis Duran came from Spain in 1994 to work at Carrefour, the big French retailer, he spoke no French. “It was total immersion from the first day,” he said. “It was shocking, but you learn fast.”

articles.headline: Lehman Battles an Insurgent Investor
articles.snippet: For eight months, David Einhorn, a hedge fund manager, has pilloried the venerable Lehman Brothers in an effort to drive down the bank’s stock price, which he is betting against.
articles.abstract: For eight months, David Einhorn, a hedge fund manager, has pilloried the venerable Lehman Brothers in an effort to drive down the bank’s stock price, which he is betting against.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Einhorn thinks another big Wall Street bank is headed for trouble  and he is not being quiet about it.
